video.title: Resume Review: Front-end Web Developer (Waqar)
video.description:
Benjamin Spak reviews the resume, portfolio & social media presence for a jr. front-end web developer role.

🎥 Benjamin's YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQUNME_uamXEW1c58iEADWw

⚠️ Want Benjamin to Review Your Resume or Portfolio?
https://goo.gl/forms/6NM27sIuXxHAoE4y1

Connect With Waqar Mohammad 💬
🐦 https://twitter.com/lawyerscode
🐱 https://github.com/waqardm/
📓 https://lawyerscode.co.uk/

Connect With Benjamin 💬
👊 Discord: http://spak.co
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/benjaminspak
⛓️ LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/benjaminspak/
🏆 301 Days Of Code: https://301daysofcode.com/

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Mnevis WebDev
topLevelComment.text: Thank you for this review this is helpful for me. I would like to know what do you think about using a coding nickname instead of the real name ?

topLevelComment.author: pyrotechnick
topLevelComment.text: Thank you this is pretty darn helpful!

topLevelComment.author: Martin Payne
topLevelComment.text: Like I’ve got Rust and C to level 6 on Codewars and Python to 5, used MatLab in an image processing class to make image recognition programs, used C to write multithreaded code in a parallel programming class, used C# to make a simple game in unity, served some files using PHP and basic http access files, wrote some Haskell banking equation programs for a Programming languages course, and done virtually all of my other schoolwork in Java. That said I don’t actually know any of those languages and only list JavaScript, HTML, CSS, Java, React, Git, Node.js, and Sass on my resume because I’m targeting web development. Is it better to just list everything ever touched?

replies.author: Benjamin Spak
replies.text: @Martin Payne I'd list SEO. It's easy to pick up if you ever need to do a deep dive for work. Might aas well list Node & NPM if you have the room; if not, then just Node IMO.

replies.author: Martin Payne
replies.text: @Benjamin Spak Thanks for clarifying! Is just following the google lighthouse audit guidelines to get SEO to 100% without having deep knowledge about whats really going on enough to list SEO or should I stay away from that unless I have deep knowledge? Also should I list both Node and NPM or is NPM implied by saying node?

replies.author: Benjamin Spak
replies.text:
A fair point Martin :) "list everything you've touched" rule isn't a hard & fast rule. It primarily applies to less technical professions where there isn't as much variance. I definitely recommend - as you mentioned - listing the tech you're both proficient with & interested in focusing on. Just listing PHP, C, C#, Java & Python, for example, will make you look like you're all over the map. However, what I am advocating, you mentioned your core focus is front-end - HTML, CSS, Javascript & React - then yes "everything you've touched" like Git, NPM, SASS, Node.js, SEO, Gulp, Web Pack etc.

I hope this clarifies what I meant :) Great question!

topLevelComment.author: Martin Payne
topLevelComment.text: I asked on the freeCodeCamp forum whether I should say HTML and CSS or HTML 5 and CSS3 and was almost unanimously told to stick with just HTML and CSS because it’s implicitly understood (and listing the number could make you look like a beginner who doesn’t know anything). I also had the opposite advice about listing everything you’ve ever used. If I list Angular , Vue, and React even though I’ve just done todo apps and the examples from the documentation that could make my statements about skills I actually have deep knowledge in like core JavaScript have less value.

topLevelComment.author: Maxime Daraize
topLevelComment.text: I feel his portfolio came from Traversy Media (responsive portfolio website tutorial) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gYzHS-n2gqU&list=PLillGF-RfqbYoGoCjKoMOkVznV6aSXKzU

topLevelComment.author: Anand Undavia
topLevelComment.text: For anyone wondering, the template of the resume is available on Google Docs Templates

replies.author: pyrotechnick
replies.text: Ah yes I remember when they first added it the resume template to google docs, I had been waiting for it lol
